prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Types of actions transferred—Particular types of actions transferred

para.paratext: There are many types of civil actions that repeatedly come before the Panel for consideration of transfer. In some of these classes transfer is virtually inevitable if the threshold requirements are met, with the only seriously contested issue before the Panel being the selection of the transferee district and transferee judge.[1] Classes of cases in which transfer is frequently ordered are set forth below.

Securities Actions. The Panel has frequently and consistently ordered actions arising under the securities laws transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.[2] These actions present many common issues of fact and the Panel has readily ordered transfer. In one decision the Panel noted:

As is often the case in multidistrict securities litigation, the prevalence of common factual issues and similar class allegations necessitates transfer of all actions to a single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings under Section 1407 in order to prevent duplication of discovery and eliminate the possibility of inconsistent or overlapping class determinations.[3]

In certain cases, however, the Panel has denied transfer of multiple securities actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.[4] Many of the securities actions transferred are brought as class actions. The Panel has given special consideration to multiple class actions because of the likelihood of overlapping or conflicting class definitions or orders and the benefits to be derived from handling all such actions in a single court for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.[5] Where there are few actions, however, the hurdle is higher, and the Panel is likely not to order transfer.[6]

Antitrust Actions. Antitrust actions present a category of actions that the Panel almost inevitably orders transferred if there are multiple actions pending in different districts.[7] Despite its general willingness to find that transfer of antitrust actions is appropriate under the statute, the Panel has also denied transfer motions.[8] Although there is a strong likelihood that transfer will be ordered where there are multiple, virtually identical cases, transfer is less likely where the cases are less similar. In one case the Panel ordered transfer of multiple civil antitrust cases involving electronic equipment,[9] but denied transfer of potential tag-along cases where they involved dramatically different market definitions from the previously transferred cases.[10]

Patent Infringement and Validity Actions. The Panel has frequently ordered transfer of multiple actions alleging infringement or validity of a patent.[11] Patent actions have also been transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with antitrust actions because of the factual similarities of the misuse claims in each type of action.[12] The Panel's willingness to transfer patent actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in appropriate cases does not prevent it from denying transfer when the actions would not benefit from transfer.[13] Transfer of multiple patent actions is frequently made less likely by the relatively small number of actions involved.[14] Although the Panel most often confronts multiple actions involving the same patent or patents, it has also ordered transfer of multiple actions involving different patents that are involved in the same product.[15] The Panel has ordered transfer of patent actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings with antitrust actions.[16] The Panel has observed that “actions involving the validity of pharmaceutical patents, in which the entry of generic versions of drugs into the market is also at issue, are well-suited for transfer under Section 1407.”[17] In 2012 the Panel addressed an argument that the America Invents Act[18] limits the Panel authority to centralize certain patent actions. Finding no language in the legislation, the Panel rejected the argument that the statute limited its authority in patent cases.[19] The Panel has also noted that there are efficiencies to be gained in having claim construction occur in all actions.

Trademark and Copyright Actions. The Panel has ordered transfer of trademark and copyright infringement actions coming before it.[20] The Panel has also denied transfer in these actions.[21] Where multiple cases are advanced at the time transfer is sought, transfer is also less likely to be ordered.[22] The panel has similarly denied transfer where the different cases involve different trademarks or copyrights.[23] The Panel has denied transfer where, despite there being numerous actions, the Panel had been advised of a trend of dismissals of those actions.[24]

Class Actions. The Panel has regularly ordered transfer of class actions involving potentially overlapping or conflicting class definitions.[25] The Panel has also expressed concern over conflicting claims to class representation and has cited that as an additional reason for ordering transfer.[26] The willingness to order transfer of class actions is likely to be overcome by evidence that overlapping or conflicting decisions will not be reached even if the actions proceed in the districts in which they were filed. In one case the Panel denied transfer where it was convinced that there was no likelihood or even possibility of overlapping determinations and no common issues of fact.[27] One particularly likely way to have class actions that do not overlap comes as a outgrowth of the Class Action Fairness Act and the incentive it creates to assert single-state class actions.[28]

Mass Disaster Cases. The Panel has consistently ordered transfer in multiple civil actions arising from a single mass disaster. Air crash cases have made up the bulk of these cases,[29] although other mass disaster cases have been transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.[30] The Panel has, however, also denied transfer of mass disaster cases in special circumstances.[31]

Product Liability Cases. Although product liability cases are similar to mass disaster cases in some respects, their treatment by the Panel has been far less consistent. Most of the apparent inconsistency is explained by the differing facts presented in products liability cases. The treatment of these cases by the Panel is, in fact, consistent with the standards generally applied by the Panel.

Product liability actions frequently result in massive discovery. Design defect and failure-to-warn claims frequently result in many similar actions pending around the country and the actions undoubtedly share common questions of fact. The difficult issues concern the balancing of benefits of transfer against the burdens imposed on the parties by transfer and the difficulty of judicial management of transferred cases. The Panel has ordered transfer of product liability cases for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in numerous cases.[32] The Panel has also denied transfer of product liability cases, and was especially likely to do so in the earlier days of the Panel's operation.[33] The likelihood that product liability actions will present cases in different procedural postures and involving different claims and theories makes it more likely that the Panel would transfer some cases and claims and not transfer others. The Panel has taken this approach in some of its decisions.[34] The Panel's decisions also reflect a particular disinclination to transfer product liability litigation that involves only a few cases.[35]

Because product liability actions arise from injuries occurring at different times, the Panel has frequently been confronted with motions to transfer multiple actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings despite the fact that the actions are in dramatically different procedural postures; some being ready for trial, others being in the early stages of discovery. This factor has been considered by the Panel and is one of the reasons transfer has been denied in actions otherwise quite similar to actions in which transfer is ordered.[36] The Panel has even ordered transfer of additional actions involving different products, creating a master centralization, including broadening the name of the MDL docket.[37] Similarly, the Panel has ordered claims by different classes of plaintiffs transferred for coordinated pretrial proceedings.[38]

The Panel has, in some circumstances, avoided “global centralization” of claims against multiple competing manufacturers in a single MDL transfer.[39] In a series of decisions the Panel has centralized several dockets of cases involving product liability claims against a single manufacturer alleging defects in its surgical products manufactured to treat pelvic organ prolapse and stress urinary incontinence. In those cases, the Panel has centralized the cases in the same district before the same judge, but has declined to create a single global consolidated docket.[40] In certain cases, however, the Panel has recognized that the benefits of having the litigation issues addressed in an industry-wide fashion justify transfer of actions against multiple defendants to a single judge and in a single docket.[41] In ordering industry-wide centralization, the Panel has noted that the transferee judge can determine the degree to which the actions are managed collectively or in separate tracks.[42] The Panel has included cases involving different products or different claimed defects in a centralization order.[43]

The Panel's willingness to consider transfer of mass tort product liability cases has evolved over the years. Although the Panel had historically ordered transfer of some product liability cases,[44] 1991 was a watershed year for the Panel's treatment of mass torts. In 1991 the Panel ordered transfer of over 25,000 product liability cases involving asbestos-containing products.[45] This transfer is especially noteworthy because it came upon the Panel's sixth consideration of the burgeoning asbestos litigation; in each of the prior cases the Panel had declined to order transfer.[46] The 1991 decision was prompted by a crisis in the federal courts relating to the flood of asbestos cases. Specifically, the Panel received a letter requesting consideration sua sponte of transfer and consolidation,[47] and reciting at some length sections of a federal court committee report that had studied the crushing workloads imposed by the asbestos litigation. In 2011 the Panel accepted the suggestion of the transferee judge in the the asbestos litigation to cease transferring additional asbestos cases as tag-along actions. The suggestion was based on the transferee judge's report that the backlog in cases was essentially eliminated and that the pending cases were lined up to be resolved by the end of 2012. As part of the Panel's order the Panel suspended the operation of Panel Rule 7.1(a), relieving the parties and court personnel from the obligation to report new asbestos-related filings to the Panel.[48]

Following the transfer of the asbestos cases, the Panel has transferred a large number of “mass tort” product liability cases.[49] The dockets in which transfer has been ordered include both small numbers of cases[50] and large number of cases,[51] though none has rivaled the asbestos case docket in number of cases. Although transfer of products liability cases is not certain, the Panel is unmistakably more receptive to using the Section 1407 transfer power to facilitate the management of mass tort cases.

The Panel has recognized the specific reference in the legislative history of the statute to product liability actions as being a type of action potentially suitable for transfer.[52] The legislative history of the statute and the Panel's treatment of it generally is discussed in § 2:3.[53]

Labor, Employment Practices, and Discrimination Litigation. The Panel has readily transferred multiple actions relating to an employer's personnel practices.[54] Actions alleging discrimination on the basis of race, sex, age, or other improper basis have also been transferred by the Panel for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.[55] Actions under the federal Fair Labor Standards Act,[56] have been transferred.[57] Not surprisingly, actions involving state-statute counterparts of the Fair Labor Standards Act have also been transferred.[58] The Panel has also denied transfer of these actions, and is especially likely to do so when only a few actions are involved.[59] In a 2010 case the Panel announced a change in approach to FLSA cases, noting that although it had historically routinely (although not invariably) centralized FLSA cases, it recognizes that these cases often “less convincing” cases for transfer.[60] Transfer is unlikely where the claims of individual plaintiffs are significantly different.[61] The Panel has also ordered transfer in related labor disputes and cases relating to employee benefits,[62] and overtime pay.[63]

Environmental Actions. The Panel has not considered many multiple actions involving environmental issues. It has, however, indicated that transfer is appropriate in such cases.[64] The Panel has also denied transfer of these cases, especially where there are few related actions pending.[65]

Sales Practices Actions. The Panel has ordered transfer of a number of cases involving challenges to sales practices of life insurance companies or their agents.[66] Similarly, litigation over mortgage lending practices may also warrant transfer.[67] Litigation involving sales practices of other products or services has also been transferred for coordinated or consolidated proceedings and has become an increasing part of the Panel's caseload in recent years.[68] Where there are few actions or other factors militate against transfer, transfer may be denied.[69]
Qui Tam/Whistleblower Actions. The Panel has ordered transfer of multiple qui tam cases arising out of the same fraud activities.[70]

Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act Cases. Since its adoption in 2003, the Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act, known as “FACTA,”[71] has generated numerous cases around the country, typically challenging compliance by a single extender of credit (either a lender or a retailer offering sales on credit). These cases have uniformly been centralized by the Panel when the minimal criteria for transfer have been met.[72] Litigation under state counterparts to FACTA are also likely to be centralized, assuming they meet the other criteria for transfer.[73] The Panel has similarly been ready to transfer similar actions brought under other similar federal statutes.[74]

“Cyber Litigation” Actions. A significant portion of the Panel's docket in recent years involve cases that share a similar origin—they arise from internet issues. They may involve accidental release of confidential data,[75] or unauthorized capture or use of information,[76] or unwelcome transmission of e-mail (spam).[77] These cases often include large numbers of claimants, multiple class actions, and numerous common issues, so frequently result in centralization by the Panel. Actions for damages for violation of statutes barring the making of phone calls or sending faxes are similarly candidates for centralization because they often involve multiple class actions and large numbers of class members.[78] As is true for many types of actions, where there are only a few cases, centralization of these types of “cyber” cases are likely to be denied for the reason that it is either unnecessary or unlikely to generate significant efficiencies.[79]

Fair Debt Collection Practices Act Cases. The Panel has been willing to transfer centralize cases under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act that otherwise meet the criteria for transfer,[80] though these cases are also often not unduly complex.[81]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
